Posts.Content: Hey, you're not being stupid at all. We all have bad days and, as anyone will tell you, the waiting time is the worst. Once treatment begins you really will feel better but until then feel free to come on here and be as grumpy as you like. We all understand. As for wanting your mum and dad, I'm nearly 60 and when I was diagnosed the person I really wanted to talk to was my mum but unfortunately she died six years ago. I think it is because our mums are the only people who know us as we really are. I know I certainly put on a 'brave ' face for everyone else but my mum would have known how I truly felt. So rant and rail as much as you like and we will try to give you the support your mum would if she could - starting with a big (virtual) hug. Xx
Posts.Title: I want my mum n dad

Posts.Content: That's great! xx
Posts.Title: 4 years on

Posts.Content: I haven't read the blog or the magazine article but I do know that no two BC stories are the same. The single mum struggling to arrange childcare around chemo, the elderly lady living alone, the builder not sure how to tell his mates on the building site that he's got BC, the woman who has 'got everything' and is therefore expected to sail through treatment but is screaming inside.  We are all individuals with our own experiences. There is no 'right' way to feel and no-one should feel guilty because they feel differently to anyone else! We all have our own journey to travel, and we all need love and understanding along the way. xx
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: Hi Nic, Yes it is possible to get BC at your age though it does become more common as you get older, and there are different types of BC. The important thing is that you have done the right thing in going to your GP to get checked out. Of course you will worry until you know for sure but hopefully you will get an answer at your appointment on Monday. Until then feel free to use this site and ask as many questions as you like but please don't 'google' your symptoms etc as there is a lot of inaccurate and out of date information out there! If your husband can go with you next week that would be great but, if not, try to take a friend with you. There will be a lot of waiting around so you'll want someone to talk to and it helps to have someone else listening to what you are told in case you forget as soon as you leave the hospital. Good luck, and let us know how you get on. xx
Posts.Title: is this normal? not possible surely?

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone, I would be interested to know how long you all waited to begin chemo after seeing your oncologists. I am seeing mine for the first time next week and thought chemo would start a few days later but I went to a scarf-tying workshop today and was told by other ladies that they had to wait another three weeks! The surgery side of my treatment all happened really quickly but it is already 11 weeks since my Mx and 4 weeks since my ANC. I really don't like the thought of waiting another 4 weeks to begin chemo. I just want to get on with it all!
Posts.Title: Waiting!

Posts.Content: Ok, I'm starting chemo next month and could do with some ideas of things to put in my 'survival kit'. I am starting it off with ginger biscuits for nausea, ice lollies for a dry mouth and lots of TLC. Anyone have any suggestions?
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: Hi, that seems a long time to wait! Could your GP get the results for you?
Posts.Title: still waitin

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for all your great ideas; my box is filling up with all sorts of healthy goodies! Never heard of Manuka honey but I'll give it a go. Don't know which chemo I'll be having yet. I have an appointment with my oncologist on October 10th. to find out. Hopefully I'll sail through it if I follow all the good advice you have all given me! xx
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: Wow Jacky.2108, That is a brilliant post! Barbara xx
Posts.Title: Can good things come from having Cancer?

Posts.Content: Yes Gillywigs, do stay! We are all at different stages on our journey and therefore come at things with our own experiences behind us. Believe me when I say that we have all had black days, and for some people those days have stretched into weeks, months and even years. Ultimately though YOU are the only person who will get yourself through it, albeit with all the  help, support and love from people around you (and that includes all the people on this site. I think if you read 'Dreamthief's post again you will see that it was in no way intended as a criticism, but rather as encouragement. We have all benefited from George's words of wisdom).  My main positive is that my three daughters are much more likely to check themselves for lumps which may ultimately save their lives. I would happily go through cancer to achieve that. Ok, maybe not 'happily' but I would certainly 'endure' it. Tomorrow is another day so I'm sending big hugs that the clouds lift a little for you. Barbara xx
Posts.Title: Can good things come from having Cancer?

Posts.Content: I have alerted the moderators to the spam reply to this post.
Posts.Title: New to the site after being diagnosed with breast cancer a week a...

Posts.Content: If you contact the Look Good Feel Better website (www.lookgoodfeelbetter.co.uk) they will help you find a session. It's definitely worth doing.
Posts.Title: 'Look good, feel better' session

Posts.Content: Hi Genny,   I had hyperemesis in my pregnancies so my BC nurse said I would be given strong anti-sickness drugs but, like you, I began vomiting a couple of hours after my first chemo. My husband called the hospital and he was told I would be fine once the anti-sickness drugs kicked in. By the next morning I was worse and my GP gave me an injection but it didn't help. That night I began hallucinating as I was dehydrated and I was admitted to hospital and put on a drip for five days.   My oncologist reduced the chemo dose before my second lot and also prescribed Emend and that helped.   Please seek help if the vomiting continues. You can be given other drugs which will help but make sure they give you them sooner rather than later.   Good luck with the rest of your treatment. Things WILL get better.   Barbara x
Posts.Title: Post 1st chemo!

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia,  I think you are right. I'll make an appointment to see my GP and see what she says. Barbara x
Posts.Title: Red mark - should I be concerned?

Posts.Content: Good morning Yvonne, Please don't feel embarrassed about asking for help and advice here. I have been completely off sex since my diagnosis in 2012, not because I am embarrassed about my body but because I am no longer interested. I was 58 when I was diagnosed so I am a bit older than you and my husband is a few years older than me. I must admit that I do occasionally feel guilty but I know my husband loves me and sex was only ever a small part of our relationship.  I too am on Anastrozole so I don't know if that has affected my feelings in any way. To be honest I think I was probably losing interest before I started taking it. I think the important thing is that you and your husband are both honest about your feelings. He sounds very understanding and I am sure he is just happy to still have you with him to share his life with!  Barbara xx
Posts.Title: I need to ask a very personal question?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, This may seem a silly question but does anyone know how far round breast tissue reaches? I had my mastectomy in 2012 followed by chemo, rads, Herceptin etc, and had a DIEP reconstruction five months ago. A week ago I noticed a red mark just behind my armpit. It looks like sunburn but isn't. At the time it was about 1 inches x 2inches but has now doubled in size. If it was on my breast I would be panicking but as it isn't I'm confused. Any ideas anyone? Thanks, Barbara x
Posts.Title: Red mark - should I be concerned?

Posts.Content: Hi again, I posted on here a couple of days ago under the heading ' bruising' but for some reason the site won't let me add to it so, to recap...... I was diagnosed in July 2012 and had mx, chemo, rads and a year of Herceptin. A few days ago my other breast became very tender, felt hard and looked bruised.  Today it also has a bright red line across it. I already had an appointment for a check-up with my oncologist today so I asked him to have a look, expecting him to dismiss it as nothing important so I was surprised when he said he would book me in for an ultrasound and biopsy!  Hopefully they will be done soon but I know I'll worry until I know the results. Just when I thought I was over the worst........!
Posts.Title: Now I'm worried!

Posts.Content: Hi, My son was 12 when I was diagnosed in 2012, He appeared to take the news very well but since then he has refused to stay overnight at friend's houses and it has taken a lot of persuading and reassurance to get him to go on a school trip next month which involves an overnight stay in London. I' m sure this is because he thinks something might happen to me while he's away.  I think all you can do is keep reassuring your child and eventually he/she will begin to relax and sleep better. xx
Posts.Title: awake - again

Posts.Content: I think you need to keep trying your 24 hour emergency number and if you can't get through try dialling 111 for advice and they will put you in touch with someone. Your resistance will be very low so you should try to keep away from infection if possible though I know it isn't always possible. Good luck xx
Posts.Title: Chickenpox!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Jaki, I'm so sorry  you have found yourself in this position. Hopefully you will be able to come through this with as little treatment as possible and then you will be able to relax and enjoy time with your baby, but if you do need chemo accept all the help you are offered. Your family will want to help you and when they say "you'll be fine" they are reassuring themselves as much as you. Feel free to come on here and rant as often as you like! Barbara xx
Posts.Title: Anyone been diagnosed after having a baby

Posts.Content: Hi, If you have finished fec then the worst is over so well done! My cancer came from nowhere. I had a mastectomy followed by Fec T and radiotherapy. I am now having Herceptin and it did affect my heart for a while but I am back on it now. I didn't notice any symptoms but it was picked up on an echocardiogram. I am also on Anastrozole. Apart from aching joints and some tiredness I am ok. A small price to pay for getting rid of cancer! Good luck with the rest of your treatment. Xx
Posts.Title: Life after FEC

Posts.Content: Hi, I would certainly go back to see your doctor and ask for a second opinion, not because it probably is anything serious but because you will worry that it is until you are know for certain that it isn't. Good luck and let us know how you get on. xx
Posts.Title: Second opinion - lump?

Posts.Content: Thanks for your replies everyone. This was my third annual mammogram. I should have had it in March but it was delayed because I had reconstruction in February. I am already annoyed because I was told that I would have mammograms on both sides but when I attended I was told new NICE guidelines said they could only do the 'non-reconstructed' side and if I had concerns about the reconstructed side (which I do) then my GP could request an ultrasound. She, however, said it will be quicker to go through my breast care unit. I'm going round in circles! I have been waiting for the results before I contacted the unit but I guess I had better phone them on Monday. The official NHS site says that we and our GPs will be sent the results within two weeks but that is obviously wrong. Oh well, what a surprise! Still incredibly grateful that we have the NHS though!
Posts.Title: mammogram results?

Posts.Content: Please don't be too hard on the friends you feel have abandoned you. Some people just don't know how to react. It may be that they have painful issues in their own lives that your diagnosis has stirred up for them, or maybe they just don't know what to say and are frightened of saying the wrong thing so say nothing at all. I told everyone about my BC and left them to deal with it in their own way. Yes I had cards, emails and offers of help from people I didn't expect to hear from and not from those I did but that's fine. We'll pick up our friendship again later. As for support, well my family has been fantastic but I'm happy dealing with this in my own way. I don't want people coming to the hospital with me. I would rather read a book during chemo than feel the need to make polite conversation. I attend consultant's appointments on my own because that way I can pass on the information I feel people need to know and keep other things to myself. I don't want people fussing and worrying if they don't need to. I have now had my mx and chemo and I'm halfway through rads. The mx didn't bother me at all, chemo was very rough but I got through it and so far I'm sailing through rads. Everyone is different and we all find our own way of coping. I found mine and I know there are people there if and when I need them but I'm happy for people to get on with their own lives too. I'm the one with BC. Good luck with the rest of your treatment. xx
Posts.Title: How to deal with how people react

Posts.Content: Me too. Can't keep up with them all!!
Posts.Title: Lost my messages!!

Posts.Content: I had my check-up mammogram done on Dec 1st but haven't had the result yet. Apparently they no longer send the results to GPs so I'm just wondering how long to leave it before I contact the hospital. I thought we were supposed to get the results within two weeks. Is it normal to wait longer? Not sure if no news is good news!
Posts.Title: mammogram results?

Posts.Content: Oh dear, now I'm confused. I genuinely feel positive and don't feel I'm suppressing anything. I guess we are all different and just have to find our own ways of dealing with things. There is no wrong or right way to feel. I'll check back in 15 years to see if my way was right for me! xx
Posts.Title: Feel like I am back at square one

Posts.Content: Help please, I'm not receiving email notifications. Anyone know what I should do? They were coming through until Saturday. Thanks.
Posts.Title: Lost my messages!!

Posts.Content: Yay, they are back!!
Posts.Title: Lost my messages!!

Posts.Content: Thanks George,  I guess I'll be patient a bit longer. Fingers crossed for tomorrow. Barbara
Posts.Title: Lost my messages!!

Posts.Content: I developed blood clots in my pelvis and lung and had to take warfarin for a year and inject myself with heparin. I know what you mean about feeling like a pin cushion!!
Posts.Title: Blood clots after chemo

Posts.Content: Hmm, not sure I would be happy with that though I guess I can understand their reasoning. I am now three years down the line but when I went for my annual check up this year I was told they couldn't do it because I had recently had reconstruction and I've got to back for it in October, That left me feeling very 'vulnerable' though logic tells me that a few months extra wait will not make any difference. I think we all just need that reassurance! xx
Posts.Title: One year check - discharged!

Posts.Content: I'll be thinking of you and sending you a hug xx
Posts.Title: My poor son's inquest tomorrow

Posts.Content: A new Keeping Abreast outreach group is starting in Diss. The first meeting will be held on Thursday 20th August from 11.00 am - 1.00 pm at the Park Hotel, Denmark Street, Diss, IP22 4LE. I have attended their Wymondham group and found it a useful place to meet people who have had, or are considering, reconstruction. For more information visit the Keeping Abreast website or call their office on 01603 667431.  Barbara xx
Posts.Title: New Keeping Abreast outreach group in Diss

Posts.Content: I agree. There is always someone out there to give advice, have a laugh with or lend a 'virtual' shoulder to cry on. x
Posts.Title: This is the best BC forum!

Posts.Content: Wow Hudson. That is such a powerful message! Your Annie was a very lucky lady to have you and I am sure she knew that. True love does indeed see beyond appearance. Thank you for posting this xx
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: Hi Nancy, So sorry you are having a rough time. Why not try writing down exactly how you feel and then giving that letter to your nurse?. It is often difficult to find the words when we are in a difficult situation. Good luck xx
Posts.Title: Tumour on my shoulder

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne, I had my mx in July 2012 and I didn't have drains put in. I had a little bit of fluid build up after a few days which my BC nurse drained. Very simple and completely painless. Nothing to worry about. Good luck with your op. xx
Posts.Title: Does drainage happen to every one ?

Posts.Content: Last night I felt a swelling in my neck, It's just above my collarbone, just to the left of centre, and is fairly large and soft. I thought it might be my imagination but it is still there today. The lump I had in my breast was small and hard and this doesn't feel the same but I don't know what affected lymph glands would feel like. Has anyone got any ideas what the swelling could be? I'll probably get it checked out tomorrow if it is still there.
Posts.Title: Swelling in my neck - any ideas?

Posts.Content: Good morning, Hope you are feeling better this morning. If your gums are still bleeding I think you should phone the hospital for advice, though hopefully it has settled down now. I am sorry you are on your own. You will find lots of people on here happy to keep you company. It seems you were unfortunate last night and wrote on one of the rare nights when we were all sleeping!! Barbara xx
Posts.Title: bleeding in mouth following anti clotting injection

Posts.Content: Thank you. I think you are probably right though I haven't had a cold or sore throat. I will get it checked - and you should probably get yours checked again too.
Posts.Title: Swelling in my neck - any ideas?

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in July 2012 and have had mx, chemo, radiotherapy and have nearly finished Herceptin. I too have the feeling that the cancer is still lurking somewhere, though it doesn't scare me as I'm convinced I'll beat it in the end. Strange!
Posts.Title: living in fear while in remission

Posts.Content: Hi Sally, Welcome to the group and I am glad you are beginning to feel better about your situation. You will find that George and Jackie are a great source of information, wisdom, comfort and entertainment. We love them! Barbara xx
Posts.Title: Thank you Dreamthief

Posts.Content: Hi, That doesn't sound right - or fair! I was diagnosed in July 2012 and was in and out of hospital so as my contract as a teaching assistant was about to end I didn't renew it and I was able to claim Employment Support Allowance. I could only claim the contribution element of it due to my husband's income but it was better than nothing.  I hope you manage to get some help.  Barbara
Posts.Title: No financial help!!

Posts.Content: I don't know anything about PIP but I'm sure you should get ESA if you can't work. I filled in a few forms and I think my doctor and consultant had to confirm what treatment I was having but I didn't have to see anyone. Including Herceptin my treatment took 18 months so maybe that was a factor. I was entitled to the contributory element because of my NI contributions but didn't claim the income related element.  I was only able to claim it because I wasn't working as my contract had ended. I think if you are still working you are probably caught in a Catch 22 situation which isn't fair.  My advice would be to speak to macmillan. They'll be able to tell you exactly what you are entitled to. Good luck.
Posts.Title: No financial help!!

Posts.Content: I don't know anything about PIP but I'm sure you should get ESA if you can't work. I filled in a few forms and I think my doctor and consultant had to confirm what treatment I was having but I didn't have to see anyone. Including Herceptin my treatment took 18 months so maybe that was a factor. I was entitled to the contributory element because of my NI contributions but didn't claim the income related element.  I was only able to claim it because I wasn't working as my contract had ended. I think if you are still working you are probably caught in a Catch 22 situation which isn't fair.  My advice would be to speak to macmillan. They'll be able to tell you exactly what you are entitled to. Good luck.
Posts.Title: No financial help!!

Posts.Content: Hi, That doesn't sound right - or fair! I was diagnosed in July 2012 and was in and out of hospital so as my contract as a teaching assistant was about to end I didn't renew it and I was able to claim Employment Support Allowance. I could only claim the contribution element of it due to my husband's income but it was better than nothing.  I hope you manage to get some help.  Barbara
Posts.Title: No financial help!!

Posts.Content: Thanks to everyone for your support. Never been keen on rollercoasters but this is one I'll have to stay on till the end! One daughter has suggested pink hair and one thinks blue, like Marge Simpson, would be a good look! Husband is suggesting red - wonder if that means he has always had a secret thing about redheads!
Posts.Title: Just told I need chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi everyone I was diagnosed in July too. I thought the lump I found was probably a cyst as I had had a mammogram a few months earlier and that was clear! Turned out to be cancer and I had a mastectomy and sentinal node biopsy. I went back in on Thursday to have more lymph nodes removed as they found one tiny cancer cell in the sentinal node and I'm now waiting for the results of the biopsy on those. I'm optimistic that everything will work out well as the lump was small but it was all a great shock. Still feels like it is happening to someone else as I feel fit and well! Hope things go well for you all.
Posts.Title: impending masectomy

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I had a mastectomy and sentinal node biopsy in July and then axillary clearance two weeks ago. Cancer was found in sentinal node and one other so consultant says I need chemo, followed by radiotherapy and hormone treatment. Well if Cancer survives all that I'll be amazed!! Have to say hospital and GP have been great and I have a lovely breast nurse so sounds like I'm lucky. Also have a very supportive family. We'll get through this together. Now, what sort of wig to go for.........!
Posts.Title: Just told I need chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi Lyn, I had my mx at the end of July and it was much better than I expected! I was treated as a day patient so didn't need pyjamas - just wore a hospital gown - and didn't have drains put in. It was a bit tender for a couple of days but to be honest I just wanted rid of the lump so feeling a bit sore didn't seem to matter. I had lymphatic node clearance two weeks ago and my arm feels 'tight' and uncomfortable but again, it is worth it! Next stage is chemo, beginning next month. Big question is......what colour wig? Hope your daughter's op goes well. Barbara x
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: Thanks for the advice everyone. I'll speak to the breast reconstruction nurse about the questions I have regarding recurrance etc. I would also like to know more about what to expect after the op. Not sure I like the idea of drains. I didn't have any after my mastectomy or lymph node clearance. On the other hand, it would be good not to have to wear my prosthetic boob when I am swimming - and my daughter is getting married this summer and I could have a 'new' figure. Oh, I just don't know!! I'll let you know what I decide. Thanks again. Xx
Posts.Title: To have reconstruction - or not!

Posts.Content: A year ago I met the plastic surgery team to discuss my options for reconstruction. We agreed on the DIEP flap and I was placed on the waiting list. I was then given a provisional date for September, then October, then November..... Finally I have been given a 'definite' date of February 12th. The trouble is that I'm not sure I want it now! It is two and a half years since my mastectomy and to be honest being without a breast doesn't bother me that much. Do I really want to put myself through a long operation and recovery period? I also worry that it would be more difficult to spot any recurrance of the cancer. There are days when I think of course I should have it done as I know people who have gone through it say they have never regretted it, ( and I'll get a free tummy tuck), but I also have days when I think it isn't worth it. I just can't decide. Maybe I should just toss a coin! Xx
Posts.Title: To have reconstruction - or not!

Posts.Content: Hi Rily, I am sure Dreamthief or Mistymoley will be able to give you lots of information but I just wanted to say try not to worry (easier said than done I know). After I found my lump I visited my doctor who referred me to the breast clinic at the hospital. I had a phone call the next day with an appointment for one week later. As my hospital has a 'one stop shop' I was lucky and all my tests were done at that appointment and I was given the diagnosis the same day. That was a Monday and I had a mastectomy on the Friday so it all happened very quickly. Obviously every case is different and while I was happy to get everything sorted quickly I know other people have to wait for results and  /or choose to take time to consider their options. I just wanted rid of the lump as soon as possible! Of course your daughter's lump may be nothing to worry about (fingers crossed) but you know that there is always lots of help, support and love on here for you both xx
Posts.Title: Daughter

Posts.Content: Hi Rily, I found it relatively easy to cope with my own diagnosis but I dread one of my children getting a serious illness. I think parents would always prefer to go through it themselves. If anything good has come out of my BC it is that my daughters are much better about checking themselves for lumps. Does your daughter live near you? Are you able to go with her to see the doctor? You will feel better about things if you are involved, particularly because of her hearing problem.
Posts.Title: Daughter

Posts.Content: I have read a lot on here lately about the decisions people are making about conventional vs alternative treatment, mastectomy vs lumpectomy etc. Of course everyone is different and must choose their own path but for me there was no decision to make. I want the best possible chance of living to see my children grow up and get married etc, and enjoy retirement with my wonderful husband. I have a fantastic medical team who have been very kind and supportive and I trust them completely. When I was told I should have a mastectomy because the lump was close to my nipple I agreed immediately and had the operation three days later. What is a breast compared to my life? I am beginning chemo etc next week and of course I am not looking forward it but it is a necessary evil and I am so grateful to all those women who have taken part in trials in the past to enable me to have the best treatment they can offer me. I am also thankful that I live in a country where the treatment is available and I don't have to worry about paying for it. We all moan about the NHS occasionally but it is fantastic when we really need it! So I will beat this thing with all the expertise that is out there! Good luck to you all, whichever route you choose to take. xx
Posts.Title: Decision? What decision?!

Posts.Content: Thanks, Terry, for telling me about your very brave Dad. I am so pleased he was able to spend the extra time with his family and I am sure he left you all with wonderful memories! Thanks to him, too, for taking part in the trials to help others. It is great to hear of your friend's recovery too! xx
Posts.Title: Decision? What decision?!

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I had my first Tax and Herceptin last week and since then I have had a horrible, hot, peppery taste in my mouth. The only thing I feel able to eat is jelly (which won't keep me going for long). Has anyone else gone through this and found anything that helps? And how long is it likely to last? Any advice gratefully received! xx
Posts.Title: Advice please!

Posts.Content: Thanks Sue and Karen, I'll try your suggestions. Water does taste awful and I can't wait to enjoy a cup of tea again! Hopefully it won't last much longer. Barbara xx
Posts.Title: Advice please!

Posts.Content: Having finally got my head around having my Diep next week I got a call today to say it has been postponed again. Grrr!!
Posts.Title: Reconstruction postponed -AGAIN!!!

Posts.Content: Did anyone watch Bang Goes the Theory on BBC1 this evening. It gave a very good explanation of how cancer cells work, radiotherapy etc. Well worth watching on iPlayer if you missed it.
Posts.Title: Bang Goes the Theory

Posts.Content: Wow, what a roller-coaster of emotions you have gone through! You have every right to feel angry at the turmoil you have been through. Mistakes happen but, as you say, it doesn't take much for people to check their facts before delivering devastating news. I hope you get an apology and answers as to how this happened. In the meantime I think you deserve to spoil yourself with wine and chocolates!! xx
Posts.Title: Told I was misdiagnosed and it's NOT bone secondaries, it's Avascular...

Posts.Content: Hope you both feel better soon x
Posts.Title: G n j
